posts.name: Luca Carvalho
posts.cooked:
Hi,

We started testing our elevator, beginning with the arbFF constant. For testing purposes, I created a command that stops the elevator from applying any output when the button is not pressed

(sorry for the bad quality picture)

IMG_1914 2 1920×292 69.6 KB

IMG_1914 2 1920×292 69.6 KB

IMG_1914 2 1920×292 69.6 KB

Here is what set elevator duty cycle does

Screenshot 2025-02-15 at 20.03.15 1712×494 79.1 KB

Screenshot 2025-02-15 at 20.03.15 1712×494 79.1 KB

Screenshot 2025-02-15 at 20.03.15 1712×494 79.1 KB

Here is what the set function does with the motor

Screenshot 2025-02-16 at 00.06.00 1728×378 52.7 KB

Screenshot 2025-02-16 at 00.06.00 1728×378 52.7 KB

Screenshot 2025-02-16 at 00.06.00 1728×378 52.7 KB

Well, when we tested that command, we noticed that it actually changed the commands the elevator was running. However, when we set the motor to a duty cycle of 0, it doesn’t stop, which I found somewhat counterintuitive.

Here is the zoomed-out graph. You can see that the elevator is executing .set(0) on the motor, as indicated by the state being “manual_duty_cycle_elevator,” yet the applied output remains greater than 0.

IMG_1910 1920×1440 187 KB

IMG_1910 1920×1440 187 KB

IMG_1910 1920×1440 187 KB

Then, here you can see that the setReference of the MAXmotion runs one time, after this, it seems like the motor is using closed loop forever

IMG_1912 1920×1440 255 KB

IMG_1912 1920×1440 255 KB

IMG_1912 1920×1440 255 KB

I was wondering if this is the behavior of the arbitrary feedforward, and what I could do to stop this motor, while using it with MAXmotion and the arbFF

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
This is bizarre, and not how this should work. Intuition would be for set to cancel any closed loop control and accompanying arbFF.

CarvalhoJeo:

and what I could do to stop this motor, while using it with MAXmotion and the arbFF

Assuming you have an extra PID slot, I should think calling setReference() while specifying a set of PID gains that are zeroed out with an arbFF of 0 should cause it to stop moving. But if this behavior is consistent, it should really get a firmware fix.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
The Spark .set() will disable the onboard PID , until such time that something else re-enables it with a .setReference call. This is likely what’s happening.

At a glance, it seems like the commands written here do not actually require the subsystem, and thus would not halt defaultCommands, or eachother from running. This would result in multiple motor instructions per loop, with the last in the internal event queue effectively “winning” and telling the motor what to do.

If you can’t spot the error yourself, posting a link to your github, or including the code here will help.

posts.cooked:
I tried using the setReference for duty cycle, with the slot but giving 0 to arbFF, and it didn’t worked Screenshot 2025-02-16 at 17.37.39 1710×160 32.6 KB

But I will try to changing the slot too and test it on monday and update this

posts.name: Luca Carvalho
posts.cooked:
Here is the link to our RobotContainer code

I believe that the runEnd command is requiring the subsystem, also we tried using only duty cycle for this type of command, a command that basically runs the motor when the button is pressed and stops when it isn’t and it worked fine

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
You’re calling setPositionReferenceMotionProfiling() from the periodic() method (indirectly) of your scorer subsystem. As far as I can tell, the manualControl field is what determines whether this runs is at all.

If I’m following the logic correctly, manualControl has to be set to false for the MAXMotion to run. Is this correct?

I ask because I think I see what’s happening here, but with the current state of your code it’s a little unclear. If manualControl is getting set and left to false, setOutput() will get called once like it’s supposed to, only for setPositionReferenceMotionProfiling() to get called again next loop and resume the output.

posts.name: Luca Carvalho
posts.cooked:
thatnameistaken:

If I’m following the logic correctly, manualControl has to be set to false for the MAXMotion to run. Is this correct?

You’re correct, thats why we initialize the variable as true. And in this version of the code, the variable never gets its value changed.

I messed up and I placed a outdated file to git, so the test position method was giving a value to the goal ( goalElevator = x ), now it’s using directly the setPositionReferenceMotionProfiling() . image 786×132 8.47 KB The problems i’ve faced were with this updated version

image 786×132 8.47 KB

image 786×132 8.47 KB

posts.name: AfterTen
posts.cooked:
Some thoughts.

You’re setting a closedloopramprate of .5 seconds. I wouldn’t do that.

Your POSITION_FACTOR_MOTOR_ROTATION_TO_MECHANISM_METERS is set to 1 so either you are, for now, ignoring this conversion or one rotation of your motors lifts your elevator to 1 meter? My assumption is it is being ignored and when you do a setElevatorTestPosition(1) you are just trying to get the motor to go to one rotation via the motor encoder.

Be careful, you are using MaxMotion and your config has the ability to configure a FF value into your PID config. You are passing in PID .arbFF into the FF slot of your PID . Granted this value is currently set to 0.0 but if you change that constant then you will be applying this value to the FF slot of the PID which is bad (not a disaster but bad) for MaxMotion control.

That being said I’m not sure what you are trying to accomplish with the way you have your buttons set to commands.

As the currently GIT posted code runs I assume you have manualControl set to false so that setScorerStructureGoals doesn’t run. I assume this is what is going to be implemented once you have a good handle on running the elevator.

That being said I’m not sure what you are trying to accomplish with the way you have your buttons set to commands.

If you hold button B it sends a command to the superStructure to have the motor go to position 1

But releasing the button doesn’t end the command, the elevator will still try to seek and hold position 1 until you hit button B. At that time, your end command runs and sets the elevator motor to zero output so the elevator should, hopefully, slowly fall under the weight of gravity and your pivot would start moving until it reaches its limit.

Last I assume when testing you have non-zero values for P, D, Max_Velocity, Max_Acceleration, Position_Error_Allowed

We are using MaxMotion for our 3 stage elevator. For testing our elevator slow values are 1500 for velocity and acceleration, my kP is .2 and my kD is .01. We feed in a constant 0.37 volts as the arbitrary FF unless the elevator is at rest at it’s lowest position then it’s zero. We found the 0.37 by testing different values.

Not saying use these value because I have no idea how your elevator is built but just to give you some reference.
